title: Lucy Bronze mum explains how England star managed to play on with broken leg
body_text:
Lucy Bronze's mum explains how England star managed to play on with broken leg at Euros
Lucy Bronze's mother has spoken how her daughter's sport sciences studies helped her to win the Euros despite playing with a fractured leg
Lucy Bronze's mum has shared how her daughter's sports science background enabled her to triumph at the Euros while competing with a fractured leg. Diane Bronze appeared on BBC Woman's Hour to reveal how the Northumberland defender acquired her fitting middle name of Tough.
Speaking from Switzerland, the proud mum discussed how many of Lucy's Lioness teammates and the extended family were aware of her broken tibia. Ms Bronze revealed: "We knew all the way through.
"Initially somebody remarked, 'Well, it can't be a fracture, because you wouldn't be able to stand up'. But she said, 'I've got high pain threshold, and I can deal with pain'.
"Obviously, we knew the medics checked it, and they knew what they were doing.
"She did a sports science degree. She reads research papers and she knows about injuries.
"That's how she can keep going. That's why she knew how to tape her own leg."

When questioned about her feelings regarding her daughter competing with a fracture – which her mother said happened in June – Ms Bronze chuckled: "It doesn't matter how I feel, it's what she's going to do." She explained Lucy's club Chelsea were informed about playing through the fracture, stating: "The amazing thing is that the medical team all knew about it, we knew about it, I think a lot of the girls knew, and not a whisper got out."
Ms Bronze explained her maiden name was Tough, and following marriage she maintained the tradition of her husband's Portuguese heritage by retaining it – meaning her children are all Toughs. She introduced herself: "I'm Diane Tough Bronze.
"When you get married in Portugal, you just add your husband's name. You keep your own and add his, so all of my children are Tough Bronzes."
Her mother confidently predicted that Lucy will continue her football career, stating: "I think Sarina (Wiegman) had it right. She's going to have to get her off the pitch in a wheelchair."
The England team won a successive Euros championship after beating Spain in a penalty shootout in Basel on Sunday.
